Description: Sand stone dice. Holes for points, filled with lead (only seven survive, rest have fallen out). Laid out like modern dice with opposite sides adding up to seven. Made of very hard stone with well rounded quartz grains in a hard yellow matrix.
Curator's comments: Probably from Egypt. Numerous solid six-sided (cubic) dice, predominantly of limestone with drilled pips (but also of faience, ivory, marble, pumice and terracotta) were found at Naukratis. Parallels known from the 7th century BC, but are particularly popular in the Roman period (Cool 2016, 229-231). Cool, H. E. M. 2016. The small finds and vessel glass from Insula VI.1 Pompeii: Excavations 1995-2006. Oxford: Archaeopress, Roman Archaeology 17.

Since the holes were filled with lead, the dice was rigged. For another example of rigged dice from Naukratis, see Oxford, Ashmolean Museum AN1896-1908-E.3744. This latter specimen presents several sides with high numbers (two sides of six and even two sides of seven!).
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (TH.05)
